name: abyss
comments: Since the default k-mer size to run an assembly is 64, we have compiled two additional images with --enable-maxk=128 and --enable-maxk=256.
Please see the documentation.
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'results' to point to the directory (under data) where results will be generated.
Note that this directory must exist before running the analysis as ABySS won't create it.

name: adops
description: Phylogenetics and detection of positively selected sites

name: afterqc
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the FASTQ file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input.fq to the actual name of your input file.

name: alphafold_db
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the file with the Uniprot ID⁠'s of all proteins for which a structure will be downloaded from the AlphaFold DB.
Additionally, this will be the same directory where a folder with the resulting structures will be created.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: uniprotIDFile to the filename of the list of Uniprot ID's corresponding to the proteins that you want to obtain from AlphaFold.
Each line in the file should contain only one Uniprot ID.

name: alter
comments: To see the ALTER help, just run help
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to align.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input to the actual name of your input file.
output to the actual name of your output file.
out_format to the output format you intend to obtain (the allowed standard formats are: ALN, FASTA, GDE, MEGA, MSF, NEXUS, PHYLIP and PIR).

name: autoaugustus
comments: To see AUGUSTUS general parameters help, you just need to run: augustus --help.

name: bdbm
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that you want to have available at BDBM.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: /your/repository/dir to point to the directory where you want a repository to be created.

name: bioconvert
description: Interconversion of life science data formats
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input file you want convert
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'bioconvert-conversion-name' to the name of the conversion command (e.g. fastq2fasta).
'input' to the actual name of your input file.
'output' to the actual name of your output file.

name: bowtie1
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input file/files you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'genome.fna' to the name of the fastq file with the genome from which the index is built.

name: bwa
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the FASTA file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: command to the specific command of the BWA tool.
options to the specific options of the BWA tool (these options will include the input/output files, which should be referenced under /data/.

name: ccp4
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input folder with all protein structures you want to analyze.
Additionally, this will be the same directory where a folder with the results will be created.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'inputFolder' to point to the folder that contains the protein structures to analyze.
'outputFolder' to point to the folder where sub-folders with the results for each submitted structure will be saved, as well as the configuration file for PISA.

name: clustalomega
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the FASTA file you want to align.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: fastaFile to the actual name of your FASTA file.
sequences_aligned.fasta to the actual name of your aligned FASTA file.

name: coral
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: Note that the -f parameter indicates that the input file is in FASTA format (-fq for FASTQ files, -fs for Solexa FASTA files.)
input.fasta to the actual name of your input file.
ouput.fasta to the actual name of your ouput file.

name: cport
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the config file and the folder with the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'input_pdb_file' to point to the PDB file to be used
'chain_id' to indicate the identifier of the chain you want to use.
--pred method to indicate the method you want to use.

name: cport-like
comments: To run the custom batch script that allows running in batch mode PDB files and get results in csv format, you should create a file named config in your working directory with the following information (one instruction per line):
input_dir=
chain=
method=
Check the Docker documentation for additional information regarding the number of retries or the wait interval for a specific method
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the config file and the folder with the input files you want to analyze.

name: cutadapt
comments: To see the Cutadapt⁠ help, just run -h.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input.fq to the actual name of your input file.
output.fq to the actual name of your output file.
A negative value after -u would trims reads at the end.

name: diamond
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'command' to the name of the DIAMOND command you want to use.

'options' with the specific options of the DIAMOND application (these options will include the input/output files, which should be referenced under /data/; see Docker instructions for further details).

name: ditasser_db
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the working directory, where the retrieved PDB files will be saved.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'UniProt_list' to the name of the list, located in the working directory, containing the UniProt numbers, one per line.

name: dnasp-v6
comments: You may have to run 'xhost +' first
invocation_general: docker run -it --rm --env="DISPLAY" --volume="${XAUTHORITY:-${HOME}/.Xauthority}:/root/.Xauthority:ro" --volume="/tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix:ro" -v=/your/data/dir:/data --hostname="$(hostname)" pegi3s/dnasp-v6 wine "/wineuser/.wine/drive_c/Program Files (x86)/DnaSP v6/DnaSP6.exe"
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that you want to have available at DnaSP v6.

name: edena
comments: To see the Edena⁠ help, just run the docker image without any parameters.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input to the actual name of your input file.
/data/result to point to the prefix of the output files that will be generated by Edena.

name: emboss
comments: To obtain the help of an application, you just need to run: emboss-application-name -h (e.g. prophet -h)
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: emboss-application-name to the name of the EMBOSS application you want to use.
options with the specific options of the EMBOSS application (these options will include the input/output files, which should be referenced under /data/.

name: entrez-direct
description: NCBI E-utilities on the Unix Command Line
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: entrez-direct-command to the name of the Entrez Direct command you want to use.
options with the specific options of the Entrez Direct command (these options will include the input/output files if required, which should be referenced under /data/.)

name: fastqc
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the FASTQ file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'input.fq' to the actual name of your input file.

name: fastroot
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'input' to the actual name of your Newick input file.
'method' to either MP (midpoint), MV (minVAR), OG (outgroup), or RTT (root-to-tip). If using OG, the -g option can be used to specify the outgroups. If more than one put them between quotes
'output' to the actual name of your Newick output file.

name: fasttree
comments: To see the FastTree⁠ help, just run FastTree -help.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the FASTA file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input to the actual name of your input file.
output to the actual name of your output file.

name: feature-counts
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'file.gff' to the actual name of your annotation file in gff format.
'output.txt' to the actual name of your output file.
'input.bam' to the actual name of your alignment file in bam format.

name: figtree
comments: You may have to run 'xhost +' first.
invocation_general: docker run --rm -ti -e USERID=$UID -e USER=$USER -e DISPLAY=$DISPLAY -v /var/db:/var/db:Z -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix -v $HOME/.Xauthority:/home/developer/.Xauthority --device /dev/dri/ -v "/your/data/dir:/data" pegi3s/figtree
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that you want to have available at FigTree

name: flash
comments: To see the FLASH⁠ help, just run --help.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input.fastq to the actual name of your input file.
result to the actual name of the directory to store FLASH results.

name: freebayes
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the BAM file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'input.bam' to the actual name of your input file.
'reference.fa' to the actual name of your reference file (rCRS.fasta is included with the docker image).

name: gatk-4
comments: To see GATK 4 available tools, just run gatk --list (please note that GATK 4 does not include some tools that are included in GATK 3⁠).
To obtain the help of a particular tool, you just need to run: gatk tools --help (where tools is the tool name)
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: tools to the name of the GATK 4 tool you want to use.
options with the specific options of the GATK 4 tool (these options will include the input/output files, which should be referenced under /data/).

name: gatk-3
comments: To see GATK 3 options and available tools, just run java -jar /opt/GenomeAnalysisTK.jar -h.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: tools to the name of the GATK 3 tool you want to use.
options to the specific options of the GATK 3 tool (these options will include the input/output files, which should be referenced under /data/).

name: getpdb
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the working directory, where the retrieved PDB files will be saved.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: UniProt_number to the UniProt number to be used (only one UniProt number can be specified).

name: gmap-gsnap
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: genome_name to a given name.
k_mer_value to the value of the k-mer size you want to use.
genome_FASTA_format to the genome in FASTA format you want to use.
input_mRNA to the actual name of your input mRNA FASTA file.
output to the actual name of your output file.

name: goalign
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'goalign-application-name' to the name of the Goalign application you want to use.
'input' to the actual name of your input file.
'output' to the actual name of your output file.

name: gotree
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'gotree-application-name' to the name of the Gotree application you want to use.
'input' to the actual name of your input file.
output to the actual name of your output file.

name: graphviz
comments: Before using the graphviz image, you must prepare the file containing the instructions for building the graph as pairs of objects.
For instance, you may create a file named graph.py, with executable permissions, with the following lines of code:
import graphviz
dot = graphviz.Digraph('Graph')
dot.edge('pegi3s', 'says')
dot.edge('says', 'Hello')
dot.edge('Hello', 'World')
dot.edge('Hello', 'User')
dot.format = 'svg'
dot.render(directory='/data').replace('\', '/')
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the graph.py file.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: Nothing to be changed

name: haplogrep
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'input' to the actual name of your input file.
'out.txt' to the desired name of the output file.
You may also want to replace phylotree-rcrs@17.2 for another reference sequence.

name: human_prot_atlas
description: Filtering UniProtKB identifier lists based on Human Protein Atlas tissues
invocation_general_comments: '/your/data/dir' to point to the directory that contains the file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: 'config.txt' to the actual name of your input TXT file with the configuration parameters (see Docker instructions).
'input.txt' to the actual name of your input TXT file with the UniProtKB identifiers (in case you need convert identifiers, have a look at the pegi3s/id-mapping Docker).
'output.txt' to the actual name of your output TXT file with the filtered identifiers.
'cache_dir' to the actual name of the cache directory (optional but recommended).

name: hyphy
comments: To see the HyPhy help, just run HYPHYMP -h.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
After executing the previous command, a set of questions will be presented to you in order to define the experiment's parameters.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: Nothing to be changed

name: id-mapping
comments: The script help can be obtained with --help.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: FROM_DB to the actual name of the source database of the input identifiers.
TO_DB to the actual name of the destination database.
input.txt to the actual name of your input TXT file with the identifiers to map (one per line).
output.tsv to the actual name of your output TSV file.
The valid names for FROM_DB and TO_DB can be obtained with docker run --rm pegi3s/id-mapping list-from-dbs and docker run --rm pegi3s/id-mapping list-to-dbs, respectively.

name: kakscalculator
comments: To see the KaKs Calculator help, just run "KaKs_Calculator -h".
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input file you want to process.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: input.fa to the actual name of your input file with the aligned CDS sequences (with no sequence line breaks) in FASTA format.
The first nucleotide must correspond to the first codon position.

name: mafft
comments: To see the MAFFT help, just run mafft --help.
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the FASTA file you want to align.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: sequences.fasta to the actual name of your FASTA file.
sequences_aligned.fasta to the actual name of your aligned FASTA file.

name: mauve
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that contains the input files you want to analyze.
usual_invocation_specific_comments: output to the actual name of your output file.
input1 to the actual name of your first input genome file.
input2 to the actual name of your second input genome file.

name: mauve (gui)
invocation_general: docker run --rm -ti -e USERID=$UID -e USER=$USER -e DISPLAY=$DISPLAY -v /var/db:/var/db:Z -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix -v $HOME/.Xauthority:/home/developer/.Xauthority -v "/your/data/dir:/data" pegi3s/mauve
invocation_general_comments: /your/data/dir to point to the directory that you want to have available at Mauve.

name: maxbin2
description: Software for binning assembled metagenomic sequences

name: r_data-analysis
description: R image with common data analysis libraries such as caret, dplyr, ggplot2, etc.

name: r_network
description: R image with data analysis libraries for network analysis, built on top of r_data-analysis.

name: r_venn-diagram
description: Creation of Venn and Euler plots

name: velvet
description: Sequence assembler for very short reads

name: whiscy
comments: No longer works because the database upon which whiscy relied is no longer available

name: cport_server
comments: No longer works because some of the servers upon which cport relied stopped working

name: evoppi-querier
description: Making queries to the EvoPPI web server

name: auto-pss-genome
description: Automatic detection of positively selected sites in complete genomes

name: check-cds
description: Compi pipeline to produce valid CDS files

name: pss-fs
description: Fast identification of genes with positively selected amino acid sites for detailed analyses

name: pss-genome-fs
description: Fast identification of genes with positively selected amino acid sites for detailed analyses in complete genomes

name: two-way-blast
description: Find orthologs using a two-way BLAST (or BLAST reciprocal best hits) approach

name: trinity
description: de novo transcript assembly and quantification

name: biopython
description: Multipurpose Python tools for computational molecular biology

name: docker
description: Docker image that allows running Docker images

name: cds2gff3-maker
description: Creation of GFF3 files from CDS and genome

name: orthologs-finder
description: Retrieve orthologous genes from DIOPT or Ensembl

name: values2tree
description: Draw UPGMA trees using lists of values
